p: From the principal component analysis, two components emerged with an Eigenvalue greater than one (Kaiser criterion) and factor loadings at an acceptable level above 0.56: the first component combined variables supporting a farm expansion (expansion, intensification, specialization, change to organic), while the other component included indicators of a declining farm operation (termination, reduction, change to conventional). The two components combined explained 65.6 % of variance of the entire sample. A hierarchical cluster analysis applying a Ward’s method to the components resulted in three distinct clusters: Cluster 1—Traditional farms ( N = 14, 9.5 %), Cluster 2—Dynamic, innovative large farms ( N = 68, 45.9 %), and Cluster 3—Farms with perspective ( N = 66, 44.6 %) (Table 2).
